original_title: Proposed Anti-Terrorism Bill jeopardizes Sri Lanka’s chance of regaining GSP+ - Harsha
original_body_lines: Samagi Jana Balavegaya (SJB) Parliamentarian Harsha de Silva says that Sri Lanka’s proposed Anti-Terrorism Bill has raised concerns that it violates fundamental rights guaranteed by the country’s constitution, potentially jeopardizing its chance of regaining the GSP+ concession.

Speaking in Parliament today (May 10), MP Harsha de Silva mentioned that as Sri Lanka approaches the end of this year, the country faces a critical debate on whether it will retain its annual trade concession worth over $500 million to the European Union (EU) through the Generalized System of Preferences Plus (GSP+).
Sri Lanka’s garment sector, one of the top forex earners for the country, relies heavily on this economic lifeline, he added.

The MP who pointed out that under new regulations, the EU now requires six countries, including Sri Lanka and Pakistan, to submit applications for the renewal of the GSP+ facility, also emphasized that the EU will decide whether to grant the facility from 2024 to 2033 after evaluating compliance with various conventions related to human rights, labour rights, good governance, environmental protection, and democratic rights.

“However, Sri Lanka’s proposed Anti-Terrorism Bill has raised concerns that it violates fundamental rights guaranteed by the country’s constitution, potentially jeopardizing its chance of regaining the GSP+”, he claimed.

Losing this trade concession would have far-reaching economic consequences for Sri Lanka, particularly in the already-struggling garment sector, he said, mentioning that as the debate unfolds, the outcome will significantly impact Sri Lanka’s future trade relations with the EU.
He further stated that the country must address these human rights and democratic governance issues to retain its economic lifeline and build a sustainable future.
